privacyLaws.lawName: Indiana Consumer Data Protection Act (Indiana CDPA)
privacyLaws.description: Senate Bill 5's Indiana Consumer Data Protection Act (Indiana CDPA) safeguards the rights to privacy and personal information of the state's 6.8 million citizens and imposes data privacy obligations on businesses operating in the state or offering products or services to residents.

notice.description: A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible, clear, and meaningful privacy notice that includes the types or categories of personal data that the controller processes. It should elucidate the reasons or purposes for which the controller processes the personal data of consumers. he notice must outline how consumers can exercise their rights under the applicable regulations, including the process for appealing a decision made by the controller regarding a consumer's request. Consumers should be informed about the categories or types of personal data that the controller shares with third parties, if any. And additionally, the notice should specify the categories or types of third parties with whom the controller shares consumers' personal data.

purposeLimitation.description: Personal data processed by a controller for purposes authorized under the relevant chapter cannot be utilized for any other purpose unless permitted elsewhere in the legislation. Such processing must adhere to specific criteria: it must be reasonably necessary and proportionate to the authorized purpose, and it must be adequate, relevant, and limited to what is essential for that purpose. Additionally, personal data collected, used, or retained must consider the nature and purpose of such actions, and must be safeguarded by reasonable administrative, technical, and physical measures to protect its confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility, while also mitigating foreseeable risks of harm to consumers. If a controller processes personal data under an exemption provided by the legislation, the controller must demonstrate that the processing qualifies for the exemption and complies with the requirements outlined in this section.

securityReqs.description: A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practicesto protectthe confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility of personal data. The data security practices required under this subdivision must be appropriate to the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.

processorReqs.description: A processor must comply with the instructions provided by a controller and assist the controller in fulfilling its obligations under the chapter. This assistance includes aiding the controller in responding to consumer requests, ensuring the security of processing personal data, notifying the controller of security breaches, and providing necessary information for data protection impact assessments. Additionally, a contract between a controller and a processor must govern the processor's data processing procedures, specifying instructions for processing personal data, the nature and purpose of processing, data subject to processing, duration of processing, and rights and obligations of both parties. The contract must ensure confidentiality of data processing, deletion or return of personal data at the end of service provision, provision of information for demonstrating compliance, cooperation with assessments, and engagement of subcontractors subject to contractual obligations.

riskImpact.description: Data protection impact assessments conducted under this chapter shall identify and weigh the benefits that may flow, directly and indirectly,from the processing to the controller, the consumer, other stakeholders, and the public against the potential risks to the rights of the consumer associated with such processing, as mitigated by safeguards that can be employed by the controller to reduce such risks

dataTransfer.description: Sale of personal does not include the disclosure or transfer of personal data to an affiliate of the controller or the disclosure or transfer of personal data to a third party as an asset that is part of a proposed or actual merger, acquisition, bankruptcy, or other transaction in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller's assets

exemptions.description: Covered entity or business associate as defined in the privacy regulations of HIPAA
State, judicial department, or local government entities for noncommercial purposes
Third parties under contract with a state or government organization, when acting on behalf of the entity.
Financial institution or an affiliate of a financial institution governed by, or personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with the GLBA
Institutions of higher education are exempted
Customer data maintained by public utilities or authorities

preemption: This article supersedes and preempts all rules, regulations, codes, ordinances, and other laws adopted by a city, county, city and county, municipality, or local agency regarding the processing of personal data by controllers or processors

penalties: The attorney general may initiate an action in the name of the state and may seek an injunction to restrain any violations of this article and a civil penalty not to exceed $7,500 for each violation under this article
privateRightOfAction: Nothing inthis article shall be construed as providing the basis for a private right of action for violations of this article or any other law.

threshold.description: Controls or processes personal data of at least 100,000 consumers who are Indiana residents
Controls or processes personal data of at least 25,000 consumers who are Indiana residents and derives more than 50% of gross revenue from the sale of personal data

privacyLaws.description: Would establish in the Indiana Code a new article concerning consumer data protection, to take effect January 1, 2024. The bill as of January 19, 2023, has been referred to the Committee on Commerce, Small Business and Economic Development.
This legislation outlines Indiana's legislation on the disclosure of security breaches, specifically addressing the obligations and definitions associated with such incidents.
